2. A 43-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents with persistent vertigo that started abruptly two days ago and has not improved. He describes the sensation as a constant spinning of the environment, accompanied by difficulty focusing his vision and worsening imbalance when standing or walking. He also reports episodes of headaches and subtle weakness in his right arm that started shortly after the vertigo onset. On examination, he has vertical nystagmus that fails to suppress with visual fixation, right-sided limb ataxia, and dysarthria. There is no auditory symptom such as tinnitus or hearing loss, and no history of migraines. MRI of the brain reveals an acute infarct in the dorsal medulla, consistent with a lateral medullary syndrome. Cardiovascular workup is unremarkable, and further evaluation for a vertebral artery dissection is pursued. He is admitted for supportive care and stroke rehabilitation, emphasizing the central nervous system origin of his vertigo symptoms.

ANSWER: I’m not feeling right, honestly. I suddenly started spinning all the time, and it’s making it hard to focus or even stand straight. My head feels heavy, and I noticed my arm feels kind of weak or off sometimes.
